Hi Tim, I know what you mean about not wanting to denigrate Blue Origin's successes compared to SpaceX's. Blue Origin is learning loads about vertical landing, space capsules and is building a 2 and 3 stage mega rocket that will have a capability larger than Falcon Heavy and be reusable. Between them, SpaceX and Blue Origin look like they'll take over the entire space market. Regarding the difference between orbital and suborbital... stretch your arms out as far as you can. Imagine a massive beach ball that size, so it touches both finger tips, goes as high as you can reach upward and down to about your knees. Imagine that is the earth. The Karman line is just over 1/3rd of an inch beyond your finger tips. Suborbital up downs go that 1/3rd of an inch away from your fingers then drop back to your finger tips. The ISS and LEO objects go round and round  the earth about 1 1/2 inches beyond your finger tips at arms length. Conceptually, I think you'd agree, that's quite a big difference:-)

Good on you, Blue Origins. A little competition will help kick open the doors of space for the rest of Humanity.

I'm not sure what the person was asking, but it is not always necessary for businesses to be profitable (albeit temporarily). This is sometimes called a growth phase. Basically it is companies dumping a ton of money into something they think will pay off. Sometimes this (and this terminology is used) when a market is undersaturated (grab as big of a marketshare as possible it will grow) or in some cases it has to reach a certain critical mass to function. For example, ride sharing companies like uber offer subsidies for customers, even under their bottom line, because with more people using the service, more drivers can do it and expect to get paid a reasonable amount leading to more drivers leading to happier customers because drivers are everwhere and wait times are short. OR as another example elon taking a loss on battery tech in order to get a leg up, feeling in the future it will pay off.
TLDR: This is because money is not the only resource that can eventually be converted into money. But you still have that resource for a while (marketshare, tech advance, etc) and it hasn't been converted yet. So the question "Do space companies need to be profitable" implies "at this time". And even furthermore it implies that they probably havent been (and this makes sense for a new industry). The question implies are they ready to switch out of researchtime and into itsbusinesstime?
